body.p:
I intended to write in the course of a few days, tut the
note which I recd yesterday, induces me to write immediately, and to offer
some apology for my not calling on thee while in Richmond last week. I left
home at a time that ill suited my convenience—though I full promised
myself the pleasure of an interview with thee. After doing my little
business, I was so tired & exhausted, and had so little time left, that
I concluded, very reluctantly, to satisfy myself with a call on B. H.
Judah at the museum, and to leave with him a message for thee,
stating my disappointment & regret at being deprived of the pleasure of
seeing thee. Had I received the least intimation while there, that thou
wouldst be down, I would have remained. But I did not know that
he sent thee word, neither do I yet; but I presume so, from the fact of
thy hearing I was there. I hope therefore, my friend, thou will ascribe my not
calling on thee to the right cause; for I assure thee it would have given me the
highest gratification to see thee, if I could have found time to have an hour or
two of conversation with thee. I should have staid longer at the museum with
our friend B. H. Judah, with whose urbanity I was highly pleased; but we
were interrupted by visitors, & as I expected his duty required he should
wait on them, I withdrew. He appears to be a man well versed in Hebrew
learning, & of much intelligence; but above all he possesses I think in a
great degree, the virtue of charity; the brightest gem which can adorn the
profession of religion. It is truly gratifying to meet with a man of such
enlarged views; & the last enquiry I would make concerning him, would be,
to what particular profession he belonged? for where we see virtue & charity &
humility abound, we should never avil? about particular modes of belief.
Those amiable feelings, are in all, the legitimate offspring of the divine perfection,
the influences of which are universal, in proportion to the reciprocal action
on the part of the creature. Such being the impressions I feel towards him, I was
sorry to be interrupted, especially as I wished to gain some information from

an authentic source of the present state of the Jews, their manners &c. While in
conversation he offered me a controversial work, the letters of D. Levi to Dr.
Priestly on the merits & evidences of their respective religions. I did not intend
to write to thee until I had done reading it, but having finished the first series
& made some progress in the second, I can form some judgment of its execution.
He is a writer of very considerable talent, and great ingenuity. His exposition of
the prophecy of David was new to me: as well as some of his translations of
Hebrew terms; of which however I am no judge. The common mass of mankind
has to depend very much on the learned for a correct interpretation of many
passages of scripture, and when they differ among themselves, what are the ignorant
to do? “Who shall decide where doctors disagree”? As long as this is the case,
controversy must be endless, in respect to particular doctrines; and we must
therefore be left to do that which we know to be right, by cultivating every
virtue, doing injury to none, and practising all the good we can. This is the
end, doubtless, of the law & the prophets. Indeed, my friend, I delight to contemplate,
the practical exhibition of those sublime principles which ought to regulate our
lives, for more than the mere profession of them. To return to Levi's work,
I think many of his arguments against the new testament might be
readily answered. Sagacious critics may no doubt be able to make
many things appear absurd, which are founded on truth. For a controversial
writer though, he is very exempt from bitterness, and I am reading his book
with a good deal of interest; for I am always pleased to see both sides.
Many of his strictures are very just on the Christians, particularly when he
speaks of the animosity between different sects—a fact which I confess gives
a powerful advantage to our opponents, and which has sometimes almost
disgusted me with the name of Christian. This has been the rock on which many
have split in their search after truth, when they judged of the Christian religion
by the acts of its professors; thereby denying such a principle as vital, redeeming
religion to exist in any people. But as D. Levi himself candidly & zealously
admits, the new testament does not authorise such abberation from the law
of moral rectitude.

I should have answered thy last valued letter, received some weeks
since, but that I flattered myself I should have had the pleasure to acknowledge
it in person. I can only account for our friend J. P. Staker's not writing from

the circumstance that he received an important appointment immediately on
his return home in the Baltimore rail Road Company, which together with the
arrangements previous to entering upon its duties occupied nearly all his time.
Indeed I have only received a very few lines, at a time, from him since he left
me, though when he is at leisure I get a letter from him almost every week.
I am sorry now he did not leave his letter with me, to copy (as he wrote it in
a hurry & it required a few corrections), but I thought he could do it himself much
better. I have written to him about it, but have received no answer yet.

I assure thee my dear friend, I feel very much gratified that my correspondence
should, on account of the spirit of moderation which I sincerely felt, have recd.
such a compliment from a Jew as it did from thy friend Jacob Mordecai. It
is a very desirable thing to gain the respect of our opponents, so seldom the
fruit of religious controversy. Hard names are never productive of any benefit. I
think I have informed thee before, of the pleasure which the perusal of thy letter
by one or two of my friends afforded them, one of whom congratulated me on the
agreeable result of gaining a friend instead of making an enemy by religious
disputation. When I quoted the passage from Deuteronomy in my last letter
I was not fully aware that it was so literally complied with by the Jews.
I thought however, & I still think, that literally, the words “when thou liest
down & when thou risest up & when tho walkest by the way &c” might embrace
almost ever division of time. I did not intend to convey the idea that it
was impracticable to love God above all things: by no means. I hope & believe
it is attainable both by Jew & Gentile. If I recollect right, there were certain
parts which I underscored, some of which I thought it would be difficult to
comply with, particularly that which requires the commandment to be placed as front
lets between the eyes.

I learned from B. H. Judah the probability that thou mightest take charge
of the Jewish Congregation in Philada. If this be so, and it should compel
thee to leave Richmond before I go down again, it will produce a lasting regret
on my mind that I did not see thee when I was down. If the offer should
be accepted I yet cherish the hope that I may have the pleasure of seeing
thee before they departure. I shall be glad to know they decision on the subject.

I recd. The whig thou sent me some weeks since, but did not get the
letter which accompanied it. Please to give my respects to B. H. Judah
and believe me to be very sincerely thy friend
